This Company's system of submarine telegraph

communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice every Wednesday at about 8.80 a.m. in time for the Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice at 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival at Trieste every Wednesday at about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reaching London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and Luggage-Van attached every Saturday to the Express Train leaving Cairo at 9.30 a.m. and will be conveyed directly to the Quay alongside the steamer.

div.head: Important Announcement.
div.p: Steam Ploughing, Cultivating, Levelling and Grading.

Messrs. J. & H. McLAREN, Manufacturers of Steam Ploughing Machinery, Midland Engine Works, Leeds, now beg to announce to their friends in Egypt, that Mr. Henry McLaren, one of their principals, will be in Egypt for the month of March, 1906. He will be glad to make appointments with any interested parties to show them our steam plough tackle at work in Egypt, and will visit and inspect any lands on which it may be intended to work steam ploughs, and give must favourable prices for suitable Machinery.

He will also show them our new Patient Gaaobeah, or levelling scoop, at work, which is the most improved method of handling large quantities of sand or soil for levelling purposes which has yet been put upon the market.

div.head: THE UNREST IN CHINA.
div.p: The recent murders of missionaries, the Shanghai riots, and the wide extension of an anti-foreign propaganda in the central and southern provinces of China has obviously caused considerable anxiety in the United States, where a force of some 25,000 troops of all arms is now prepared to start at a moment's notice for the Far East. The Chinese Government, which has no desire to repeat its painful experiences during the Boxer rising, is at present engaged in informing the ambassadors of the various Powers that the Chinese in general are animated by the best intentions towards foreigners and that recent outbreaks have been caused solely by the folly of agitators and the recklessness of missionaries. The Japanese Government also appears to have assured the ambassadors of the Powers at Tokio that it has every confidence in the good intentions of the Chinese Government, but we doubt whether Chinese or Japanese assurances are likely to persuade any of the European nations that have political or commercial interests in China, to relax the preparations that all have been making for some months past in view of a possible outbreak. China is, after all, not so homogeneous that a word from the Son of Heaven or the Dowager Empress can instantly calm the anti-European agitators that swarm in many of its cities. The Boxer rising did not extend to the Yang-tse valley though for a time it was supported by the Government and whatever regular army China then possessed. Similarly, while the Government, which is strong in the Northern Provinces, would no doubt stand alone in the event of a rising in the south or centre of the kingdom, its remonstrances and threats might have little effect on the insurgents, and the very fact that the present Chinese dynasty is Manchu and not Chinese by origin makes it probable that its commands would not be disobeyed in the Yang-tse valley, where the anti-dynastic societies are numerous and well organised and where the great Taeping rising nearly succeeded in founding an independent kingdom. It is, no doubt, on this account that the Chinese War Office has awaked from its long slumber and is now organising an army that will some day be formidable in equipment and numbers, and whose beginnings have aroused the admiration of European military experts. The "foreign-drilled" troops now being raised by Yuan Shi Kai, the energetic Governor of Pe Chi Li, are not yet numerous enough to contend against the armies of Japan or of any European Power, and the day has not yet come when the Chinese will be able to cross swords with their neighbours. But disciplined and drilled troops, acting under the orders of the central Government, are precisely what the "Middle Kingdom" has lacked for centuries. Had China possessed an army instead of a collection of mutinous ragamuffins armed with masks, prongs, and arrows, the attitude of Europe towards China would have been different from the first, and the relations between the Eastern Empire and the foreigner far more friendly. China's weakness begat contempt, and a series of acts of aggression at last drove the Chinese of the North to a savage but hopeless rising and taught the Imperial Government to turn to ths once-despised Japanese as teachers. The creation of an army in China—if the new developments are permanent—will at first be an unmixed benefit to the world in general. It will conjure the European peril, making it impossible for Chancellors to demand harbours for wounded and provinces for slain missionaries, and it will make the central Government far more capable than at present of dealing with outbreaks of anti-foreign savagery. In the future the million or so of trained men that China will possess in 20 years' time may be used for purposes of aggression, but their time has not come ; the dragon, though he is awake, is still too stiff to career over Asia, breathing out flame and smoke and calling for the intervention of a new St. George.

div.head: Insalubrious Establishments.
div.p: The Public Health Department has issued a circular according to the terms of which premises in which cotton seed oil is sold are henceforth to be classed as being among unhealthy establishments. According to this decision, the proprietors of there premises most procure a "rokhsa" and fulfil all the usual formalities.

div.head: Church Services.
div.p: The preacher at St. Mark's, Alexandria, tomorrow at 11 a.m. will be the Rev. F. B. N. Norman-Lee, S.C.F. The preacher at All Saints' Church, Ramleh, at 11 a.m. on the same day will be the Rev. J. J. Lias, M.A., Chancellor of Llandaff Cathedral, late Professor at St. David's College, Lampeter, and Hulsean Lecturer at Cambridge.

div.head: Defrauding the Municipality.
div.p: An interesting case is coming before the Supreme Consular Court in its approaching sessions at Alexandria, and it will be of considerable importance as a question of principle. The complainant is Mr. Max Carasso, Assistant Director of the Tax Collection Department at the Alexandria Municipality, and he alleges that Messrs. Carmel Bohagiar and Antoine Buhagiar of Rue Souk el Manakai, Alexandria, conspired with Ibrahim el Lewa to cheat and defraud the Alexandria Municipality in order to diminish the amount they had to pay the Municipality for their house tax. It appears that these men incited El Lewa to make and sign a fiotitious lease.

div.head: Walker and Meimarachi Ltd.
div.p: Mr. Constantine Meimarachi, the able managing director of Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., is leaving Alexandria for Trieste this afternoon by the Austrian Lloyd steamer. He will visit Vienna, Dresden, Berlin, Paris, and London on a tour of inspection in connection with this company. At the various capitals he will observe the great stores and shops so as to bring the great establishment which is to house Walker and Meimarachi at Cairo up to the level of any similar store in Europe. Mr. Meimarachi will return to Egypt in about six weeks' time. He is accompanied by his well known architect, Mr. Antoine Lasciac. The foundation at me of the company's raw building will be laid on the 1st May.

div.head: THE KAREIMA LINE.
OPENING CEREMONY.
LINE COMPLETED IN EIGHT MONTHS.
div.p: In the presence of a large and enthusiastic crowd of natives, officials, etc., H.E. the Governor-General of the Sudan, Major-General Sir P. R. Wingate, as already announced, opened the new railway line connecting Kareima with the main line near Abou Hamed on Thursday last.

The proceedings opened with an address by El Lewa Jackson Pacha, C.B., the Governor of Dongola province, followed by an account of the new line by El Kaimakam Midwinter Bey, D.S.O.. Assistant Director of Railways.

His Excellency the Governor-General, in his speech, congratulated El Miralai Macauley Bey, Director of Railways, and especially El Kaimakam Midwinter Bey, who was in charge of construction works, on finishing the new line, 138 miles in length, in eight months, at a cost of about £250,000.

The rich Dongola province is thus bronght 500 miles nearer to the sea than before, and a market will be provided for its cereals and dates, not only in the Sudan but possibly also in Arabian and Red Sea ports.

H. E. the Governor-General presented the following decorations, conferred by his Highness the Khedive : El Sagh. Mohamed Eff. Fadil, 4th Osmanieh ; El Sagh. Ibrahim Eff. Sayed, 4th Osmanieh ; Mr. Clement Gaukroger Hodgson, 3rd Medjidieh; Mr. Henry Valentine Hawkins, 4th Medjidieh ; Mr. George Bertram MacPherson Grant, 4th Osmanieh ; Mohamed Agha Wad Kansish, 5th Medjidieh.

The following officers, officials, etc., were present at the opening ceremeny : El Lewa Slatin Pacha, El Kaimakam Hayes Sadler Bey, El Miralai Stack Bey, Mr. Bonham Garter, El Kaimakam Charlton Bey, El Bimbashi Vaughan, and El Bimbashi Collins; also Lady Wingate, Miss Danford, Mrs. Bernard, and Mrs. Stack.
At the conclusion of the speeches H. E. the Governor-General pulled off the signal, allowing the engine to proceed through the decorated arch.

div.head: EGPYT AND TURKEY.
THE GERMAN PERIL.
CORRESPONDENT'S REVELATIONS
div.p: Our Suez Correspondent reports that the Nour-el-Bahr sailed from that port yesterday forenoon for Akaba with despatches.
H.H.S. Aida is leaving Alexandria for the Gulf of Akaba on Sunday night. It is expected that she will be employed in running despatches between Akaba and Suez.

Gheziret Faraon (the Island of the Pharaohs) is most interesting. It is only a quarter of a mile long and 400 yards wide. It is surrounded by an old Saracenic Castle, which is believed to date from the time of the Crusades.
It is considered very significant that the Constantinople local Press has been forbidden to discuss the subject.

The Constantinople correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" says that the British Embassy at Constantinople is much surprised by the Turkish Government's action in raising the district of Akaba to the rank of a sandjak, including it with the sandjaks of Medina, Mecca. Yambo, and Jeddah, in the province of Hedjaz. This action may be due to the growing importance of Akaba as the future terminus of the Hedjaz railway, or to a scheme of the Turks to make a delimitation of the frontier necessary.
We extract the following from a London contemporary :—

A correspondent, whose position enables him to speak with accuracy and authority, writes to me from Cairo : —"There has been no little interest taken here in the Akaba incident. Turkish troops, as you know, passed the frontier, and caused Egyptian troops to retreat before them. The latter, indeed, were on the point of evacuating the island when, under British direction, some additional men and a gun were landed, and the place was fortified. Since then H.M.S. Diana has been ordered to the spot. I am told by a trustworthy informant, that there are 400 Turkish troops on the frontier but the really significant point in the whole business is that all the engineers on the new railway are German officers with their uniforms in their baggage. This will probably be denied, but you may confidently take, it from me that it is a fact."
Our contemporary continues :—

The Akaba incident is now closed, the Sultan having yielded, and withdrawn his forces from Egyptian territory ; but the troops and the Germans are not far off. The Gulf of Akaba, of course, is the north-eastern extension of the Red Sea, and the circumjacent territory is within the Khedive's dominions. The object of the recent Turkish demonstration is quite plain. The Sultan does not ordinarily take steps which are a challenge to Great Britain, but he is the Kaiser's protege and he is deeply involved in financial transactions with Germany. If we make ourselves disagreeable to the Berlin authorities about Morocco, and by a too genuine support of France, the Sultan is to be used to show us that we are not, as we fondly supposed, only vulnerable by Germany on theses. We are to discover that, upon occasion, our expulsion from Egypt might be attempted by the troops of the Padishah, officered by Germans, and appealing, no doubt, to Mobamedan sentiment in the Khedive's country. The German-Turkish threat is a smart piece of bluft, and it is just as well to remember that as Egypt can be menaced from Asia, so can the Sudan from Abyssinia.

It is to be hoped that this manueuvre will open the eyes of those well-meaning but egregiously mistaken people who are clamouring for an entente with Germany of the kind which would prompt us to show confidence by undoing or avoiding every preparation that might make the Germans suspect we were ready for war with them. If, say these worthies, we prove our pacfic intentions by showing that we are unprepared for attack, the Germans will lay aside their mistrust, and pure, lasting friendship will be the up-shot. No doubt many excellent Germans desire this, as do their counterparts in this country. But German State policy is determined by the political and geographical conditions of Germany, and these conditions render a decisive war with Great Britain almost inevitable sooner or later, and entirely justify it from the German point of view.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
div.p: ROUGH WEATHER.

div.head: FATAL ACCIDENT ON A STEAMER.
div.p: Port Said, Friday.

Tuesday, afternoon and evening, was one of the roughest days we have had here for a long time, and many accidents occurred, one of which proved fatal. Shortly after 2 p.m. the wind rose with sadden rapidity and in less than ten minutes was blowing a gale. In the Canal the weather was as bad, if not worse, and the resale was that no less than seven vessels went ashore. While the S.S. Merton Hall was tieing up at Kil. 54 the forecastle head block broke, owing to the strain of the ship, which was broadside on to the wind. When the block gave way, the wire rope which was at the time in use straightened itself out and in so doing broke down the railings and caught the chief officer in the chest, the unfortunate man succumbing very shortly afterwards. At the inquest held at Port Said a verdict of "Accidental Death" was returned.
The Clan Cumming.
The S.S. Clan Camming, of which we heard so much last September, arrived here on Tuesday from Bombay, having had a safe passage through the Canal.
The Pilot Question.

With reference to the Minerva's hasty passage through the Canal to assist the Donegal, all ships had orders to tie up, so as to allow the Minerva to get to Suez as soon as possible. The pilot, however, who by the way was a Greek, found difficulty in making more than 4 1/2 to 6 knots, whereas the regulation speed for the ships in the Canal is 7, so there was no time saved. It is a great pity that Britishers are not sent on all Government ships, especially when it is an urgent case like this.
Football.

On Thursday Port Said played another team from H.M.S. Minerva. Both sides put a weak team on the field, but in spite of this a very fast, interesting, and sportsman-like game was played, and ended in a goalless draw. The chief point in the game was the grand defence of the goalkeepers, Brookes, the Port Said man, being in the best of form. Mr. Gunnery also played a very fine game, but unfortunately just before the end hurt his knee and had to retire.

div.head: CRUISE OF AMERICAN SQUADRON.
div.p: VISIT TO ALEXANDRIA.
Rear-Admiral Sigsbee and an American squadron are due to arrive at Alexandria from Syria on Monday morning. The men-of-war include the Brooklyn, the Tacoma, and the Chattanooya.
The squadron has been on a visit to Beyrout to support the demands in the Note handed to the Porte on February 18 by Mr. Leishman, the United States Ambassador.

These demands are principally with reference to the elevation of the Ottoman Legation at Washington, and of the American Legation at Constantinople, to the rank of Embassies, and concerning the Porte's recognition of the legal existence of American schools and charitable institutions in Turkey.

In the Note above referred to a protest was made against the delay of eighteen months in the fulfilment of the Porte's promise to recognise the legal existence of American establishments. A demand was also made that the United States should yet the same treatment as is accorded to France. Mr. Leishman insisted on an immediate reply to the requisitions.

It is not yet known how long the squadron will remain at Alexandria. A number of the wives and families of the officers arrived this morning and are being accommodated at the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute.

div.head: THE "CADRES."
div.p: The Commission appointed to consider the reform of the cadres of the Government employes met to-day and will continue to meet each Thursday and Saturday until it has accomplished its labours.
In this connection the "Progres" says :—

A ce propos nous croyons savoir, que le conseiller financier attend que le travail de la commission soit acheve, pour arreter le mode de repartition de la somme de L E. 130.000, qui a ete mise a sa disposition pour l'augmentation des appointements des employes du gouvernement.

Il ne semble pas que Sir V. Corbett ait l'intention de faire une distinction entre les differentes categories d'employes. Il va sans dire tontefois, que les plus faiblement retribues seront les premiers a faire l'objet de sa sollicitude. Il verra ensuite jusqu'ou lemoyens dont il dispose lui permettent d'aller. Autant dire qu'il lui sera impossible de donner satisfaction a tout le monde. Mais on peut etre sur d'avance que la repartition du credit alloue par le gouvernement sera faite avec l'impartialite et l'equite qui caracterisent le conseiller financier.

div.head: FROM CAPE TO CAIRO.
HARDY LADY EXPLORER.
HER JOURNEYINGS ACROSS AFRICA.
div.p: Miss Mary Hall, whose exploits have already been noticed in these columns, has now successfully accomplished her journey from the Cape to Cairo, and is enjoying a short time of comparative quiet in the Capital before leaving again for home and England. To see and talk with Miss Hall, it is difficult to believe that fifteen years ago she was obliged to abandon the artist career she had chosen for herself on the score of ill-health. Whatever ambitions she sacrificed then she has now received fall compensation, for besides having gained perfect health she has taken a unique position as being one of the very few travellers, and certainly the only woman traveller, to have found her way from one end of this great continent to the other. It was on account of nervons strain and breakdown from overwork that Miss Hall took her first trip to India, and, having once tasted of the fascinations of travel, she has devoted most of her life since then to exploring the world. She has spent months in Alaska, Honolulu, and the South Sea Islands, has lived in Burmah and the Far East, and has made friends all over Australia. She has the capacity of making friends everywhere, and owes evidently much of her success to her genial personality.
Never Felt Nervous.

In talking of her wanderings up and down the globe Miss Hall is always ready to credit those she met with the utmost kindness and civility, and it is easy to realise the powers within herself that called forth these corresponding traits. It is given to very few women to be able to take a huge solitary journey, like her latest, entirely dependent upon her own resources, and to be able to state at the end that she met with no untoward accidents and that throughout her journeyings across savage tracts of land she had never cause to feel really nervous. We shall hope to read her own description of her travels before long, for her experiences will be worth hearing, and many a domestic housewife at home may gather hints for her household management from the way in which Miss Hall kept peace with her party of native servants and looked after their welfare.
Exploring S. Africa.

Previous to her latest venture Miss Hall had spent some twelve months exploring South Africa, working her way through the Transvaal and into Rhodesia and even further a field. It was during this year that she happened at Buluwayo about the time of the completion of the railway to the Victoria Falls, and through her acquaintance with Mr. Pauling and others she was enabled to make that journey before any other woman but Miss Pauling, who had driven the first train into Livingstone a short time previously.
Journey Determined on.

It was during there months of wandering on the borderlands of Central Africa that Miss Hall met friends whose business had taken them still further into the interior, and it was through them that she became fired with the ambition to do what no other woman had yet done and find her own way across that huge space of little-known country which divides North and South Africa. Her first scheme had been to start her travels at Mombasa and work her way across to Lake Victoria Nyanza, from thence to Lake Tanganyika, and southwards to Chinde by that long waterway of lakes, etc., but further considerations caused her to alter her decision, and future events showed the wisdom of her choice. Naturally her friends and relations did all they could to dissuade her from embarking on so perilous an expedition, but her mind once made up she would not abate her decision, although she stipulated to return at once should any unforeseen difficulties present themselves during the earlier stages of the journey.
With the Missions.

The earlier part of the long route from Cape Town to Chinde was taken by sea, and at Chinde Miss Hall was provided with passes, tent equipment, and all the necessary outfit for the overland journey as far as Kituta by the African Lakes Corporation, of whose assistance she speaks in terms of highest praise. The journey by land and lake and across the long Stevenson road to Lake Tanganyika was accomplished without any mishap, and, though Miss Hall had to wait many weeks before the arrival of any steamer to take her North, the enforced delay proved afterwards to have been a blessing in disguise. This time of inaction was in no way a waste of time, for Miss Hall found good friends at the various missions in the neighbourhood, Dr. Hetherwick's at Blantyre, the University mission at Lekoma, and the Livingstonia and the London missions all being visited by her, and all of them showing every kindness and favour that lay in their power.
Her One Regret.

The one regret that Miss Hall would seem to feel in her journeyings is that she was never able to land upon the Congo country, for the steamers by which she travelled confined their attentions to the eastern shores of the lakes, aod the only places she explored were on that side. After disembarking at Usambura, Miss Hall made preparations for the most difficult portion of her travels, for there lay before her some three hundred miles of uncivilised country across German territory to Bukoba on Lake Victora Nyanza. Her party for this long and dangerous route consisted of some forty servants and porters, besides a small escort of soldiers kindly granted her by the German official. Doubtless danger was very near her all these twenty-eight days, but Miss Hall's absolute fearlessness and ready resourse stood her in good stead and she came triumphantly through all obstacles. Her accounts of her dealings with her servants and their little peculiarities will all make for pleasant reading when her book is published.
Across the Lakes.

Arriving at Bukoba Miss Hall made the tour of the Lake Victoria Nyanza and then struck North from Mengo to Lake Albert Nyanza, which she traversed by rowing boat, camping on shore during the night-time. She continued by boat up the Nile as far as Nimule, where the difficulties of navigation forced her to continue her journey overland. Civilisation awaited her at Gondokoro in the shape of a tourist steamer with many long-forgotten luxuries on board, and though Miss Hall had many hundred miles yet to cover, her active adventures were practically over.
Plenty of Grit.

Looking back upon her seven months' wanderings Miss Hall declares that rarely, if ever, she felt lonely or nervous, for the days passed in quick succession and she always had plenty of occupations and interests. She has brought back a great store of photographs which will be of immense interest, and she has also kept a very complete diary which will doubtless prove the groundwork of her book. Even in these days of enterprise Miss Hall's travels entitle her to a high place in the annals of adventurous Englishwomen. The modest way in which she attributes her success to every cause but the right ones, her genuine pluck and stirling sound sense, are enough to arouse the admiration of every one of her countrymen and women and shows that there is plenty of grit left in the breed, whatever pessimists may argue to the contrary. We await Miss Hall's own account of her travels with considerable impatience.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Leopold of Battenberg arrives at Cairo to-morrow.
The Archduke Joseph of Austria and the Archduchess Augusta and suite are on their way to Assouan and expect to arrive at the Cataract Hotel to-morrow night.

Lord Alexander Thynne, brother of Lady Cromer, and Sir Hugh and Lady Shaw-Stewart, the brother-in-law and sister of Lady Cromer, are paying a visit to the Fayoum. Yesterday they were the guests of Major Elgood, Inspector of the Ministry of the Interior, at Medinet el-Fayoum. They left that town during the day for a trip to the desert beyond Abou-Hamed, where the Remah Bedouin tribe live. To-day they are going for an excursion to that beautiful part of the Fayoum known as the "Egyptian Switzerland."

Lord Alexander Thynne is the son of the fifth Marquis of Bath and was born in 1883. He was educated at Eton and Balliol and has fought an election for the Unionists in Somerset, had a seat on the London County Council, soon some fighting in the Boer War, and acted as Reuter's Special Correspondent in Somaliland.

Lady Cromer's brother-in-law, Sir Hugh Shaw-Stewart, is the seventh baronet and is the head of a family whose estates in Renfrew have lineally descended in an uninterrupted course of male succession from Sir John Stewart, son of Robert III. of Scotland. The present baronet was educated at Eton and Oxford and entered the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders. He has bean a member of Royal Commissions on deer forests and on physical training. He married Lady Alice Thyune in 1883.
Lady Boughey has left Cairo for England as Sir Thomas Boughey is lying seriously ill at his residence, Aqualate, Newport.

Our contemporary "Al Mokattam" has received the news from Abyssinia of the death of Major-General Sir William Gatacre, which took place near Adis Abeba. He was the brother-in-law of the Hop. A. J. Davey of Cairo, having married the third daughter of Baron Davey in 1895.
Mouseigneur Joseph Derian, Maronite Archbishop of Egypt, arrived at Port Said by the Senegal on Wednesday, and arrived at Cairo at 11.20 p m. on the same day.
Don Antonio de Beneducci, the Mexican Consul-General for Egypt, who has been seriously ill for the past six weeks from Malta fever, is, we are glad to hear, now convalescent.

The Rev. R. L. Page, the Superior-General of the S.S.I.E., Cowley, is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 14th inst. He will be the guest of the Rev. and Mrs. N. Odeh, St. Mary's Mission, Kasr-el-Doubars, and hopes to spend a month with them and help in the services of St. Mary's Chapel, especially the Good Friday and Easter services.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe last night : The Archduke Joseph and Archduchess Augusta and suite, Mr. Vater, Mr. Ricke, Mr. Dimstraki, Mr. Engels, Mr. Webb, Mr. Shields, Mr. and Mrs. Campbell, Mr. D. de la Marlais, Mr. J. P. du Condeay, Mr. and Mrs. Goldman, Mr. Lowe, Mr. Sanderson, Mr. and Mrs. Godlee, Mr. Mulchland and party of 5.

The Austrian delegate has submitted a scheme for a Franco-Spanish police force with a Swiss or Dutch Inspector General. M. de Radowitz has accepted a Franco-Spanish police force if under international surveillance. He said that Macedonia and China proved the advantages of joint European control.

M. Revoil announced that France was prepared to give fresh guarantees for commercial equality if the Conference would agree to a Franco-Spanish police system. It is believed that the Austrian proposal was inspired by Germany. (Reuter)
France regards the appointment of a Dutch or Swiss inspector as a complication which would be inacceptable, bat everything points to satisfactory compromises on the main points. (Reuter)

div.head:
FIGHTING IN THE PHILIPPINES.
OUTLAWS EXTERMINATED.

div.p: After three days' fighting, the American troops, naval contingents from the warships, and the Philippine constabulary exterminated 600 outlaws who were holding a steep fortified mountain, near Iolo. All the outlaws were killed. The Americans lost 18 killed and 52 wounded. (Reuter)

At the opening of the Chamber, Signor Sonnino announced the introduotion of numerous measures for the improvement of the Southern provinces, including the purchase of railways and the reduction of the land tax with a view to preventing emigration. (R.)

div.head:
FRENCH CABINET.
M. SARRIEN TO FORM MINISTRY.

div.p: M. Fallieres has asked M. Sarrien to form a Ministry. M Sarrien is consulting his friends. (Reuter)
M. Faillieres has asked M. Sarrien to reconstitute the Cabinet. M. Sarrien will reply after having consulted his friends. (Havas)

div.head:
THE BRITISH EMPIRE.
AREA AND POPULATION.

div.p: The first census of the Empire shows an area of 12,000,000 square miles and a population of 400,000,000. (Reuter)
Princess Ena and her mother have left for home. (Reuter)

div.head: OIL AND COAL IN EGPYT.
div.p: The Department of Mines of the Ministry of Finance has drawn up a standard prospecting license for persons, who are authorised to prospect for petroleum, cleagenous substances, oil, shales, coals, lignites, bitumens, mineral waxes, and any bituminous substances on all Government lands in any part of Egypt (except the Valley of the Nile or the Peninsula of Sinai) which are not included in any lease, exclusive license, or prospecting-area and are not occupied by the Government for official purposes or by any other person by authorization of the Government for any purposes, and are not lands ordinarily or from time to time cultivated or lands which the Government shall at any time declare to be reserved for cultivation. This license form has received the approbation of the Council of Ministers. Mr. J. F. Wells, the Inspector General of Mines, is to be congratulated on having drawn up such a carefully compiled form of license.

div.head: SCIATICA AND KIDNEY DISEASE.
div.p: Patient Wheeled About in a Bath-Chair for 3 Months.
Specialist Declared Mer Incurable.

Mr. Henry Boxer, living at 38 Westlake Road, Rotherhithe, London, England, writes:— Gentlemen,—I feel I must write and thank you for the great good my wife is deriving from Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. This time last year she was so ill with sciatica and kidney disease that she entirely lost the use of her limbs, and was unable to stand. I had to carry her about the house like a baby. The doctor said that if I did not get her out of London I should not have her very long, so I got her down to Sheerness to some of her relations, who were very kind to her. She was wheeled about in a bath-chair for three months, and although the change of air did her good, she was still unable to walk when she returned home. made her a pair of crutches, which improved matters a little, and at this time a friend advised us to try Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. some for my wife, and she seemed better after the second or third box, so she persevered with the medicine, and ever since then she has good headway. She does not get the awful pains in the back, and she is quite another woman. I have got her 80 boxes of Doan's Pills altogether, and her remarkable cure is the talk of the neighbourhood.
"Either of us will be only too glad to speak for Doan's Backache Kidney Pills any time, and you are welcome to publish this letter.—I am, gentlemen, gratefully yours,
Hr. BOXER.

Some months after receiving this letter, we sent our representative to see Mrs. Boxer. "I still in splendid health to-day," the grateful woman said, "and can get about the house nicely, as well as help with the housework, still use Doan's Pills occasionally, for I find they keep me in such good health.

"Yes," Mr. Boxer joined in, "and I wouldn't like to be without a box of Doan's Pills in the house, for they have saved my wife's life. Since I wrote yon last, she has been down to Sheerness again, but, thank goodness, not to be wheeled about in a bathchair, for she can walk well as anyone, and our relations in Sheerness are astonished at her cure. Before she used Doan's Pills, no one thought she would live, and for nine months she was unable to leave her bed. A specialist in kidney troubles, who had her case in hand, said to me : "I don't like to tell you, but there's not the slightest hope of your wife pulling through ; her disease is one that nothing can cure.' A local doctor, too, said: 'It's no use my coming to see your wife any more ; I can only give her the same medicine over and over again, and I can never do her any good ; she is past a cure."

"However, I wouldn't give up hope, and I kept trying different medicines uutil I heard of Doan'a Pills. Before my wife had finished the third box she seemed going right ahead, improving quickly, and she has been well, as yon see her to-day, for a long time. Words cannot tell you how grateful we are for the happiness Doan's Backache Kidney Pills have brought to our home."

Doan's Dinner Pills are sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 13 per box, or P.T. 71 for six boxes ; or they may be bought direct from the general agent for Egypt, Max Fischer, Mousky Street, Cairo.

div.head: JUST OUT. REISSUE WITH
div.p: Orographical Map of the Nile Valley.
OUR SUDAN
BY JOHN WARD, F.S.A.
Assisted by Sir RECINALD WINGATE and his] Officers, Sir WILLIAM GARSTIN, Lt.-Col. COUNT CLEICHEN, and others.
Dedicated by request to
LORD KITCHENER or KHARTOUM.
Crown 4 to 400 pp. 720 Illustrations. PRICE 21st net.
Letter from Sir Rudolf von Slatin.

Dear Mr. Ward,—Your delightful and most interesting book on the Sudan has reached me. I congratulate you heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written and illustrated. All of us who have done our little beat to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have received more than kind treatment at your hands... I don't suppose anyone realises more than I do the change that has come over the Sudan since my old and tyrannical master the Khalifa disappeared from the scene. Yonr description of the 'Peace and Progress' is, in fact, a sequel to my 'Fire and Sword in the Sudan.'
With kindest regards, believe me,
Yours sincerely,
RUDOLPH V. SLATIN.
JOHN MURRAY, LONDON.
To be had of all Booksellers in Egypt.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The vacant appointment of Commandant of the Indian Staff College has been filled by the selection of Brevet Lieutenant Colonel Thompson Capper, D.S.O., East Lancashire Regiment, an old officer of the Egyptian Army, and a participator in the battles of Atbara and Omdurman.

Captain L.A.E. Price Davies, V.C., D.S.O., 1st Battalion Ring's Royal Rifle Corps, who has received orders per cable to leave Cairo for home, will take up the duties of Adjutant and Quartermaster of the School of Instruction for Mounted Infantry, Longford, on arrival, in succession to Major V. Henry, Royal Fusiliers, who has reverted to regimental duty on promotion.

Captain Herbert Street, 90th Hussars, Brighton, with which regiment he served during its final tour in Egypt, has been selected for the adjutancy of the Lothians and Berwick Imperial Yeomanry, Dunbar. Captain O. W. Brinton, 91st Lancers, who rode with that smart regiment in its maiden charge at Omdurman, has been appointed adjutant of the North Somerset Imperial Yeomanry, which has its headquarters at the pleasant town of Bath.
Lieutenant Cookerell, Royal Berks Regiment, who was a supernumerary since taking up duty with the Khedive's Army, has been restored to the establishment on ceasing that employment.

The Rifle Depot, Winchester, is about to receive the short magazine rifle, charger packed ammunition, and bandelier equipment in consequence of the home battalions of the K. R. R. C. and Rifle Brigade being about to be re-armed with that weapon.

Rear-Admiral E. S. Poe, commanding the East Indies Squadron, has been promoted viceadmiral, getting the vacancy caused by the death ot Sir Harry T. Grenfell, second in command of the Mediterranean Fleet. Vice-Admiral Poe was appointed to his present command some six munths ago, and as it is a rear-admiral's command he will vacate it, but hardly till be has completed a year any way. This well-known Irish officer gets his second flag at a little over 44 years' service. He has substantial records of useful service in the Navy, though he has never seen any war service, but that is not his fault.

The naval estimates for 1906-07, just issued, show that economy is to be effected by reducing the stores of our first line of defence, and by a reduced shipbuilding programme. This is the recognised policy of the Radicals, a cheeseparing one for the time being, to be followed by the expenditure of money like water when it is too late. The personnel of the Fleet is to be the same as last year—122,000 of all ranks. The total estimated expenditure is £31,869,500 as against £3,389,500 last year, the decrease is principally in material — that is, naval stores —and reduced expenditure in shipbuilding, repairs, maintenance, etc., amounting in all to a net decrease of £1,520,000. The shipbuilding programme includes the construction of four battleships, five oceangoing destroyers, twelve coastal destroyers, and the same number of submarine boats. In addition, twenty-nine other ships, commenced whilst the late Government was in power, will be completed, and work on twenty-two other ships will be well advanced. Ot the four new battleships, one will be built at Portsmouth, one at Davenport, and the other two by contract. Lord Tweedmouth hopes that the battleship Dreadnought will be ready for commission early next year, and the Agamemnon, and Lord Nelson will be completed by their contract dates.

The cruiser Lancaster, Captain F.L. Tottenham, attached to the Third Cruiser Squadron, Mediterranean Fleet, will complete her commission in a few weeks. She will return home to Devonport, pay off, and re-commission for another turn of duty in the Mediterranean. The Lancaster will recommission on the 30th inst. with a crew of 700 all told. She did very well in gunnery during her present commission.

div.head: Slaves to Spring Catarrh Restored to Health by Pe-ru-na.
div.p: SPRING THE TIME TO CURE CARARRH.

div.head: Pe-ru-na invigorates Mind and Body.
div.p: Hon. Wm. G. Hunter, Ex-member North Carolina Legislature, writes from the Census Office Building, Washington, D. C., as follows:
"The greatest family medicine ever discovered, In my opinion, which comes from experience as well as observation, la Peruna.

"The most common sanction to humankind is a bad cold. Peruna drives it out of doors, wards off catarrh, invigorates and gives fresh strength to mind and body. I give Peruna my unqualified endorsement."—Wm. G. Hunter.

div.head: Takes Pe-ru-na Every Spring.
div.p: Miss Tilly Marx, 421 14th St., Milwaukee, Wis, writes :
"I am pleased to endorse Peruna, as I found it very efficient in ridding my system of a severe cold and catarrhal trouble, after I had tried many other remedies without getting relief.

"I took Peruna for two weeks, when I was much better, and in two weeks more I was entirely rid of the cold and catarrh. I shall take it every spring as a tonic, as I found that it made me much better in every wey." ––Tilly Marx.
Miss Lydia Herziger, Grand Recorder of American Daughters of Independence, writes from Mronah, Wis., as follows :
"I have used Peruna now for four years, each Spring and Fall, and it keeps me perfectly well and strong.
"I am able to continue working and do not have to take a three months' rest, as I used to do every year. This is a great comfort to me, as I was not able to afford such a long rest.
"I find that it is great preventative for colds and coughs and soon rids the system of all discase and is an admirable medicine. I can honestly endorse it." ––Lydia Herxiger.
Spring Catarrh.
Almost every one has come to believe that spring is a season that brings derangements of the body dependent on blood impurities.
This belief is an old one, is nearly universal, and has arisen, not as the result of the teachings of the medical fraternity, but has been learned in the bitter school of experience.
Nervous Depression.
Depression of the nervous system at the approach of spring is a fertile source of blood impurities.
There are general lassitude, dull, heavy tired feelings, with poor appetite, and sometimes loss of sleep.
The Tired Feeling.
That tired feeling, which is the natural result of the depressing effect of warm weather immediately after the invigorating cold of winter, quickly disappears when Peruna is taken.
The Proper Remedy.

Peruna meets every indication and proves itself to be perfectly adapted to all their varied peculiarities. Peruna invigorates the system, rejuvenates the feelings, restores the normal appetite and procures regular sleep.
Do Not Delay.

Get a bottle of Peruna when the first languid feelings make themselves apparent in the spring. Take it according to the directions on the bottle. Continue this treatment through the first months of spring.
This course of treatment is no experiment; It is as positive in its results as any fact of science can be.
A Spring Tonis.

Almost everybody needs a tonic in the spring. Something to brace the nerves, invigorate the brain, and cleanse the blood. That Peruna will do this is beyond all question. Everyone who has tried it has had the same experience as Mrs. Winnifred Power, an artist, who, in a recent letter from 246 7th St., Portland, Ore., says:

p.hi: "I am pleased to speak a good word for Peruna, as I found it an excellent tonic and spring medicine and very effective in ridding the system of cold and catarrh.

div.p: "About two years ago my system was all ran down in the spring and I thought I would try and see if Peruna would be of any assistance in bringing back my health and strength.
"I found that it was splendid and all the medicine that I needed. In a little over a month I was well and did not need to take any more medicine.
"I shall recommend it to every one in need of a tonic, and know that I have only to take a few doses of Peruna when I take a cold and I will soon be over it." —Winnifred Power.
Nature's Assistance.
Spring is the best time to treat catarrh. Nature renews herself every spring. The system is rejuvenated by spring weather. This renders medicine more effective.
A short course of Peruna, assisted by the balmy air of spring, will cure old, stubborn cases of catarrh that have resisted treatment for years.
A Word of Advice.
To those who have been afflicted with chronic catarrh we wish to say that the spring season affords yon a splendid opportunity to get rid of your disease.
It may be you have been afflicted for several years; you may have tried different remedies. Perhaps you have become discouraged.
Now is Your Opportunity.
This failure was during ths winter months. But now is your opportunity. Nature comes to your assistance at this season.
Just help her a little and she will bring you out of the quagmire in which you have been floundering so long. Give Nature a little assistance lost her struggles be in vain.
A Typical Case.
Geo. M. Fillmore, late 1st Lieut. 3rd U.S. Artillery, writes from 900 L St., N. W., Washington, D. C., as follows :
"I brought forward from winter into spring a sickening case of catarrh which was making existence miserable for me, until I was induced to try a bottle of Peruna.

"An immediate improvement gave me hope, if not relief. I kept up taking Peruna and it has so strengthened and relieved me that I am now confident of a cure. I heartily endorse Peruna for catarrhal affections and as a tonic for their weakening effects."—Geo. M. Fillmore.

p.hi: A short course of Peruna now will be just in time. During the month of April you will find the strategic time to rid yourself of chronic catarrh, one of tha most persistent, stubborn diseases in the whole list of human aliments.

div.p: After you have tried it you will say Peruna is positively the best spring medicine you have ever used.
A great many years of extensive trials of this remedy in this class of derangements have demonstrated that there are no failures.
Thousands of Testimonials.
Thousands of cases might be quoted in which Peruna has rescued people from the ravages of spring catarrh, and put them on a good, solid foundation of health.

We can give our readers only a slight glimpse of the vast array of unsolicited endorsements Dr. Hartman is constantly receiving. No other physician in the world has received such a volume of enthusiastic letters of thanks.

If you do not derive prompt and satisfactory results from the use of Peruna, write at once to Dr. Hartman, giving a full statement of your case and he will be pleased to give you his value his advice gratis.

div.head: CAIRO BILLIARD TOURNAMENT.
div.p: The first two matches of the annual billiard tournament for the benefit of the markers of Shepheard's, the Continental, and Ghezireh Palace Hotels took place at Shepheard's Hotel on Wednesday evening before a large number of interested spectators. On this occasion Percy engaged Syer and Flowers and was victorious in both his matches, though in either ease he only won by a narrow margin.

The first match was between Percy and Syer, and at 9.33 p.m. Percy, who received 60 points start, having won the toss, played the spot ball into baulk and this was followed by a safety miss from Syer. At the commencement neither player got away and several visits were made to the table without substantial result, after which Percy gave a pretty break of 17, in which he showed some good all round play. Syer replied with 22 and left Percy a double baulk and very shortly afterwards Syer compiled a neatly-played 19, but left Percy an easy winning hazard off red with a consequent audition of 15 to his score. Syer, who had apparently settled down to a good game, responded with 11, failing at the end at a difficult masse cannon, and play continued evenly for a time. Percy was the first to reach 100 slightly in advance of the handicap, but Syer gradually crept up to his opponent with breaks of 16, 17 and 27 and with a splendidly compiled 59 overtook Percy at 130 and gained a lead of fifty-five. Percy responded with 10, and Syer then made 16, but after that the former compiled 34 in three visits to the table, while Syer failed to increase his score at all. Syer, however, passed 200 while Percy's score was 184 and play was afterwards very even until Percy tailed at an easy losing hazard off the red and let in Syer, who increased his score by 23. With the score at 249—129 in favour of the scratch man —Syer gave a foul but responded to Percy's miss in baulk with a splendid all-round-the-table cannon, but only added 7. Percy's turn, however,came shortly and he gave breaks of 21, 11, 3, and 23, while Syer scored 2 and so got within 12 of his oppontnt. The next break of note was 22 from Percy by which he led Syer by 4, the scores then being 280—276, and each then went to the table twice without scoring. Percy got away next and compiled 14, making the scores 294—278, and Syer increased to 289 and then 294, Percy meanwhile scoring 4. With the game standing at 298–294 in Percy's favour the excitement was intense, aim Syer on going to the table attempted to leave the balls safety but felt instead an easy had-ball screw pocket off white, which Percy mace and so ran out winner by the narrow margin of 4 points.

div.head: PERCY V. FLOWERS.
div.p: The game between Percy and Flowers proved to be as exciting a one as the former, though at the opening it looked as if Percy had an easy game on. Flowers received 75 and Percy 50 aud after the former had made 11 in two breaks, the latter gave a splendid exhibition making a most neatly compiled break of 40. Another break of 30 gave Percy a lead of 29 with scores of 122––93 and some very level play was then seen but Flowers made a good 27 and following this with 17 and 12 led Percy by six. With the exception of breaks of 32 and 18 from Percy, who again led by 25 and 37 and 11 from Flowers, play was very quiet, but with a series of small breaks Flowers again over-took Percy and led by 7 with the scores at 253––246. Indifferent play from both men followed until Percy overtook Flowers with a break of 11, the scores being 287-278. Flowers next to took the lead with the soores at 288-287 but Percy eventually won by 9 points.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: As already announced, the racing season at Alexandria will commence with a Skye Meeting on the A.S.G. grounds on Monday, 24th inst. The other racing fixtures for the season are as follows :—Shem el Nessim Skye Meeting, April 16 ; First Summer Meeting, May 3 and 5 ; Second Summer Meeting, May 24 and 26 ; Third Summer Meeting, June 14 and 16.

div.head: MINIEH SKYE MEETING.
div.p: A Skye meeting with five events will be held at Damaris, Minieh, on the l8th inst. at 10 a.m., under the presidency of Suliman Bey Osman, Moudir of Minieh. Omar Pacha Sultan, Messrs. J. P. Hopkins, T. G. Raihes, E. N. Haselden, and Moh. Bey Moussa are the stewards, and there is every reason to anticipate a very successful day. Omar Pacha Sultan is presenting a valuable cup to be competed for by gentlemen riders, over a 5-furlong course, the events being open to horses owned by residents in the provinces of Minieh, Beni Souef, Assiout, anil Fayoum.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 9 mars.

A Londres, le Consolide anglais est reste hier invarie a 90 3/4. L'Unifiee a baisse de 1/4 a 105 1/4. La National Bank et la Daira Sanieh sont demeurees inchangees a 27 5/8 et 17 7/8. L'Agricole a reagi de 1/8 a 10 1/8.
A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier Egyptian a reactionne de 5 francs a 792. La Banque d'Athenes s'est maintenue a 144.
Notre marche a ete, ce matin encore, tres anime sur le groupe des titres dont nous avons parle hier, groupe anquel il faut ajouter anjour-d'hui les Oasis et les National Hotel.
La National Bank et l'Agricole, delaissees, ont plus ou moins cloture aux memes prix qu'hier. La Cassa di Sconto a avance a 210.
L'action Credit Foncier s'est inscrite a 793, et l'obligation a lots 1886 a 341. L'lmmobiliere a progresse a 389 et la part de fondateur a 540. L'Union Fonciere a fait 6 11/16.
L'action Entreprises Immobilieres et de Travaux a monte a 4 9/16 ; la part de fondateur, qui a en les honneurs de la matinee, a hausse de 12 1/2 a 17 acheteurs, gagnant L.E. 4 ½ en une seance.
L'action ordinaire Khedivial Mail est revenue a 42 sh.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les National, en bonne demande, ont avance a 4 5/16—3/8 et las Baehler a 6 1/4. Les Nungovich ont cloture a 16 5/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, grand mouvement sur les Oasis, qui ont gague 1/4 de livre a 1 7/16 acheteurs. Les Estates ont fait 2 1/16 ; la part de fondateur a attaint 11 1/8. Les Cotton Mills ont avance a 7 sh. 9, lsa Markets a 25 sh. et les Egyptian Constructions a 1 3/4.

Nous disions dans notre Circulaire du 22 fevrier dernier qu'il fallait s'attendre a une hausse prononcee sur les titres de l'Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co. L'evenement nous a donne encore un fois raison. Un premier mouvement s'etait produit des le lendemain: le 23, l'action avait avance de 3 9/16 a 3 3/4, et la part de fondateur avait saute de 95 a 185 pour cloturer a 120.
Or, cette hausse s'est fortement accentuee ce matin : l'action a monte a 4 1/4 pour finir a 4 1/16 et la part de fondateur a bondi a 175 pour cloturer a 165.

On sait que les actionnaires sont convoques en assemblee extraordinaire lundi prochain, 12 mars, pour autoriser le conseil d'administration a etendre les operations de la Societe aux pays limitrophes a l'Egypte, parculierement a l'ile de Chypre, ou elle a obtenu, entre autres concessions, le privilege de fonder une Banque Agricole sur le modele de l'Agricultural Bank of Egypt.

On peut maintenant considerer cmme certain que la nouvelle Bourse du Caire sera edifiee sur la partie de l'ex-terrain Sabet, achete a la Compagnie Immobiliere d'Egypte par la Corporation des Agents de change.

L'edifice sera eleve tout pres du National Hotel. Il sera relie a l'avenue Kasr-el-Nil par une rue nouvelle qui unira cette avenue a la rue Soliman Pacha. Il eut ete difficile, on en conviendra, de trouver un meilleur emplacement dans le nouvean quartier central de la capitale.

C'est a cela qu'est du, assurement, le mouvement de hausse qui s'est dessine ce matin sur les actions du National Hotel. Le fait est que le voisinage de la Bourse est appele a augmenter considerablement la valeur de la propriete de la National Hotel and Residences Co.

D'ailleurs, l'exploitation du National donne deja de superbes resultats. L'etablissement n'a ceese d'etre comble depuis son ouverture et la Societe a du, comme on sait, faire commencer ces jours derniers des travanx d'agrandissement importants qui serout termines en antomne et feront du National un des plus grands Hotels du Caire.

Le mouvement de hausse est donc pleinement legitime, d'une part, par les belles perspectives de l'entreprise; d'autre part, par le bas cours du titre, en egard a la plus-value enorme acquise par les autres valeurs hotelieres.

A en croire des renseignements provenant de bonne source, il fandrait s'attendre a une prochaine reforme dans l'administration de la Nile Cold Storage Co. Il serait question de transformer la Compagnie, qui est anglaise, en Societe egyptienne, ou tout au moine de conferer a la direction locale les pouvoirs detenus par le Board de Londres.

div.head: Coton
div.p: Nons avons tont simplement en tont de dire dans nos precedentes revnues que rien ne pouvait nous surprendre dans les agissements de la speculation dominante sur notre marche depuis quelque temps, car ce que nous avons un cette semaine, durant les quatre premiers jours du moins, a ete tellement inattendu, qu'il a quand neme forme un objet d'etonnement pour tont le monde. Et le pins tort est queces hauts et bas par tallaris a la fois n'ont en aneune base senjeuse, aucun rachat du decourvert n'etant venu provoquer la hausee rapide du debut, et l'amelioration de 30 points en deux jours signalde de l'Amerique ne pouvant nullement jusifier une parrille allure. d'autant pins qu'il y a longtemps deja que nous marchions sans faire le moindre cas de ce qui se passait au dehors. Le fait est que c'est un veritable marche de casse-cou qu'a ete le notre et il est presque certain que persorna n'a au ou pu en profiler, des fluctuations aussi rapides et aussi sensibles ayant le don, pres-qu'in variablement, de rendre le vendeur hesitant a cause de la crainte du pire.
Voici maintenant comment les choses se sont passees:

Peu satisfaite de sa reussite de vendredi soir qui, de 18 17/32, avait porte le Mars a 18 7/8, et prenant pretexte de la hausse de 14 points qui nous a ete servie en cloture par New York, la speculation a trouve le moyen de pousser a 19 3/8 pendant la manitee de samedi. Mais ce nouveau succes l'ayant quelque peu grises, elle a condsidere qu'il n;y avait pas lieu de s'arreter en si beau chemin et comme consequence le debut de lundi matin a eu lieu d'emblee a 19 ¾ et par la suite nous avons touche 20 1/16 qui constituent le cours maximum de la semaine.

A ce point, il y a eu de nombreuses offres de ventes, et comme en meme temps Liverpool est venu faible et n'a pas repondu a l'Amerique, une reaction a commence a se dessiner et a la fin de la journee nous etions de retour a 19 1/16. C'etait marcher un peu trop vite, mais si l'on reflecbit a l'exageration meme du mouvement de hausse qui avaint precede, ce recul ne pent paraltre que naturel.

Mardi le cours d'ouverture a etede 19 7/32, pour monter ensuite a etede 19 7/32, pour monter ensuite a 19 5/8 descendre a 1 heure a 19 ¼, et remonter de nouveau dans l'apres-midi a 19 21/32, derniere cote de la journee.

Le lendemain, une nonvelle tentative des haussiers nous a re, orte a 19 15/16 comme prix le plus haut, mais le soir, apres avoir passe entre-temps par le cours de 19 ½ comme minimum, nous avons fini a 19 21/32, mais avec tendance marquee pour le calme, indi quant un arret definitif dans la course echevelce vers la hausse. Et en effet, hier, la tenue a ete chez nous beaucoup plus moderee, le premier cours qui a ete de 19 9/16 a fait place sans reprises interimaires, a celui de 19 5/16 affiche a la derniere cloture.

Ce matin finalement, apres que'ques transactions a 19 7/16, le calme a pris defi itivement le dessus et c'est a 19 5/32 que nous avors termine la semsine, ce qui reduit a 9/32 en tout l'avance depuis vendredi dernier. Ajoutons, en passant, que la petite douche qui nous a refroidis aujourd'hui consiste dans la nouvelle filiere de 12,500 cantars emise ce matin et qui parait etre un indice certain de l'elimination de tout decouvert et de la proba bilite d'une sutre emission, sinon pour le 15, du moins pour le 22 courant et qui l'quiderait completement tont restant du Mars. Du reste, cette idee tourverait en quelque sorte sa confirmation dans le fait, que le report de Mars a Mai, que d'aucuns esperaient voir diminuer, est au contraire en augumentation, et plus d'un transfent a ete opere a ces conditions.

Comme on peut le relever par l'expose qui precede, ce n'est que ces deux derniers jours que le marche est rentre dans une voie un peu plus normale et sans variations sortant du domaine de l'ordinaire, mais il serait encore premature de croire que la partie est abandonnee par les haussiers : ils sont encore trop interesses et quoique, sons l'influence de Liverpool et du ralentisement prevu des exportations, nous puissions graduellement reculer, il ne faut pas s'attendre pour le moment a une baisse reelement importante, surtont si l'Amerique vient a appuyer, par une hausse quelque peu sensible, la lutte pour le maintien des cours laquelle ne manqueront pas de se livrer les detenteurs de contrats Toutefois, il est a remarquer que l'activite n'est plus aussi grande sur notre marche, ce qui pourait etre interprete comme signe d'un certain desir de vendre de la part des haussiers pour diminuer au moins leurs positions.

La nouvelle recolte a tout naturellement ete entrainee, mais le Novembre n'a pas depasse au plus haut le niveau de 16 ¾, pour fiuir aujourd'hui a 16 5/16. D'auilleurs, il ne faut pas oublier que si les prix actuels pour la prochaine recolte trouvent en quelque sorte une justification dans ceux de l'ancienne, il n'en est pas moins vrai qu'au fond et en eux-memes ils sont purement fataisistes et leur maintien ne serait possible que par l'eutetement de la speculation : quoiqu'a des cours raisonnables, la vieille recolte a pour elle l'idee dominante qu'elle est insuffisante pour tous les besoins de l'annee mais qui saurait prevoir ce que pourra etre celle qu'on commence a peine a ensemencer? Avec la situation presente de l'Americain, la consommation ne pourra que continuer a se tenir a l'ecart et sans achats de ce cloteda, le Novembre est fatalement destine a flechir.

La demande de la part de l'Angleterre s'est arretee subitement et pour ce qui est du continent, elle est insignifiante, limitee comme elle l'est a de petits ordres pour les besoins urgents et indispensables. Ce sont la du reste, les raisons du calme qui regne sur le marche du disponsible et qui fait que les exportateurs ne s'interessent qu'a certaines qualites, c'est adire sux bons classements qui sont loin d'etre abondants. Quant aux classements inferieurs, qui sont le plus directement sujets a l'influence de l'Americain, ils sont tres negliges et cela s'explique par le fait que leur emploi, concurremment avec ce dernier ou pour son remplacement, est chose impossible avec l'ecart de prix existant. Cela nous vau ra certainement une diminution dans la consommation continentale pour les mois d'ete.

Pour ce qui est des prix leur surelevation s'est trouvee impose par la situation des contrats : elle n'est pas egale pour tontes les qualites, la cote efficielle de ce matin indiquant une hausse de 1/8 a 7/8, suivant genre et classement, mais elle est generale et les plus favorises sont les Good fair and Good Mit Affifi qui constituent les trois grades presqu'exclusivement livrables aujourd'hui contre contrats.

Les exportations, quoique importantes, n'ont pas atteint les previsions et le ralentissement provient surtout du cote de l'Angleterre. Pour cette semaine, elles ont ete dde 26,000 Balles, contre Balles 25,000 l'annee derniere, mais pour la huitaine prchaine, il y aura diminution certaine a en juger par les premiers embarquements, Il est vrai aussi que l'annee passee il y a eu aussi recul a 18,000 Balles pour la meme periode.
Par contre, le mouvement de la recolte comme recettes, bien que plus reduit, ne cesse de laisser planer le doute sur l'exactitude des estimations qui ont cours quant qu rendement de la recolte.

Liverpool a cable dans la semaine que les places d'Alexandrie du Caire etaient acheteuses de 30,000 balles d'Egyptien sur mai et que les interesses semblaient avoir l'intention d'en exiger la livrasion. Le fait pent etre vrai, mais il est impossible d'en affirmer la veracite ; en tous cas, dans une eventualite pareille on pourrait provoquer un grand monvement sur nos cotons sur le marche anglais. Seulement, a voir l'indifference de Liverpool pour l'egyptien tant disponible que livrable on serait porte a considerer l'information en question comme un simple canard, dont il est facile de sourconner la source. D'autres maisons ont aussi cable de ne pas toucher aux egyptiens et leur conseil semble etre ban, car les ventes en disponsible n'ont fait que diminuer pendant la semaine, au point que pour la journee d'aujourd'hui elles n'ont pas despasse les 100 balles. Sous le rapport des prix, on constate 1/8 de baisse sur le spot du point le plus haut, ete une hausse de 12/64 sur les futurs, comme resume des variations depuis vendredi dernier.

Les Americains, par contre, ont donne lieu a de grosses ventes en disponible, atteignant plus d'une fois le total de 20,000 balles en un jour, mais comme prix il n'y a que 14 points d'amelioration sur le spot et 13 sur les futurs. La demande set donc excellente et justifie amplement l'opinion de New York que la hausse est inevitable avec des achate aussi importants de la consummation et que le bon marche relatif de l'American ne peut qu'encourager.

div.head: Graines de Coton.
div.p: L'activite a fait defaut par suite du peu d'importance des besoins de l'exportation en marchandise prete, mais cela n'empeche pas que les cours soient restes soutenus et finissent aujour'hui a 66 1/2.

Pour ce qui est des expeditions pour mars, elles n'ont guere l'air de vouloir ere fortes, mais sans que le reveil de la demande soit deja marque, on observe deja un peu plus de frequence dans les ordres qui nous viennent de Hull. Cela pourrait un peu modifier les perspectives du moment. L'Angleterre offre actuellemeat £ 6 6/3 pour mars. On dit aussi qu'il y a du mieux tant sur les huiles que sur la grains de lin, dont la chute avait provoque la diminution de la consommation de la graine de coton depuis quelques semaines.
En contrats, il ne se fait toujours que pen d'affaires, mais les cours restent relativement soutenus.
En nouvelle recolte, pas d'affaires et la cote est nominale a 61 1/4-61 3/4 pour les 3 mois.

div.head: Rain & Rheumatism.
div.p: Impurs Blood is the true cause of Rheumatism ; Damp or Cold only excites what is in the system. To cure Rheumatism you must enrich and purify the Blood by

"I was so crippled with rheumatism that I couldn't attend to business, and I should not be alive to-day but for Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People.
That, in brief, is the record of Mr. James W. Stanley, of 6, Bonchurch-road, West Ealing, London.

"On several occasions," he stated, "I got soaked in the rain while out on business, and no doubt this excited the rheumatism that was in my blood. The pains began in my toes, but quickly the trouble spread, and I was soon in bed with rheumatic fever.

"After a terrible time I got on my feet again, but that first was followed by a series of agonising attacks. I lay helpless, unable to move, hand or foot. This would last two or three weeks at a time ; then I would perhaps do a little work until the next spell of wet or cold weather came.

"A specialist said, in addition to other troubles, I had heart disease. To the surprise of everybody I did not succumb, but after the crisis was past I could not even straighten myself owing to the rheumatism. I was sore all over, and couldn't bear even the bedclothes to touch me.

"When I did get on my feet, too ill and bent to work. I was recommended to try Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. I did, and the result was wonderful. My joints grew easy, the pain left me and I became steadily stronger until the complaint vanished."

Since then I have never had the slightest return of rheumatism. I work at all hours, rain or cold, and I realise that Dr. Williams' Pink Pills make new and pure blood, and drive out the poisonous acid that causes rheumatism."

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE.
div.p: Jusqu'ici les marches d'Europe conservent leur attitude expectante, c'est-a dire que les positions y restent insignifiantes en face d'un capital toujours grandissent. D'autre part, les evenements sont tous en faveur de la hausse : baisse a Londres du taux prive d'escompte de 3 5/8 a 3 ½ pour cent et hausse du consolide anglais de 90 ¼ a 90 ¾. Quant a la baisse de 10 centimes de la Rente Francaise a 99.47 elle provient uniquement de la chute du Ministere Rouvier. La preuve en est que plus on va, plus la solution d'Algesiras s'affirme pacifique : d'un cote la presse allemand se radoncit a mesure que le gouvernement francais montre plus de fermete et de l'autre les puissances neutres, Russie, Autriche, Etats-Unis, Italie interviennent a l'envi aupres de Guillaume. Il pour lui conseiller la paix : Edonard VII lui-meme doit avoir prochainement une entrevue avec le Kaiser, son neveu. On suggere, en outre, a la conference un projet de police qui, vu sa moderation, rencontrera sans doute l'approbation de l'Allemagne. C'est ainsi que ce cauchemar du Maroc qui a trop longtemps pese sur le marche mondial va beintot disparaitre pour faire place a la securite la plus complete, aurore d'une reprise sans precedent.

Sur les marche egyptien, le spectacle actuel de la corbeille des valeurs n'est pas sans causer quelque inquietude. Les maneuvres que nos redouctions se sont livres enx-memes a leurs exceuteurs en vendant des titres a decourvert, ce qui a entraine l'egorement prevu, et, comme consequence, une hausse disproportionnee des valeurs en question. Il va sans dire que la baisse sur ces titres sera aussi rapide que la hausse a ete factice et qu'en definitive le resultat le plus clair de ces maneuvres sera, comme l'annee passee, un marasme general plus ou moins prolonge.

A peine le decourvert mentionne aura-t-il disparu que l'attention du marche se reporters de nouveau sur les grosses valeurs, momentanement delaissees. Une reprise est inevitable, entre autres, pour la National Bank, 'Agricole, et les valeurs foncieres serieuses ; les plus-values sur ces titres prendront meme d'enormes proportions, si la question du Maroc est tranchee d'une facon definitive. Les valeurs de traction, telles que la Ramleh Railway, les Tramways et la Delta Light, ont aussi devant elles un brillant avenir par suite de l'enorme sccroissement de la population, surtout a Alexandrie, et de la prosperite grandissante de l'Egypte en general.

Ce que nous venons de dire constitue a peu pres le resume de la semaine : Les Egyptian Constructions ont fait fureur, atteignant en quelques jours pres du double de leur valeur nominale, soit 1 7/8. De leur cote les Nungovich Hotels ont avance en 4 seances de deux livres et demi. Sur l'avance de la semaine passee les Ordinary Khedivial Mail ont encore gagne plus de 8 shellings a 48 pour revenir en cloture a 43/9. Ces trois valeurs ont absorbe a elles seules toute l'attention du marche pendant cette semaine, rendant presque impossible toute transaction sur les autres titres. Il y a au cependant au certain mouvement en Estates, Cassa di Sconto, Delta Land et vers la fin, en Brasseries.

Les grosses valeurs, telles que la National Bank, l'Agricole, la Behera, la Delta Light, la Daira, les Tramways, la Ramleh, etc., ont ete completement delaissees, au profit des petites et des nonvelles emissions.

Comme fluctuations, sur un total de 49 valeurs inscrites a la cote officielle, 24 sont en hausse, 14 en baisse et 9 restent stationnaire. Deux ont ete admises dans le courant de la semaine, ce sont le Banco di Roma et le Credit Franco Egyptien qui sont cotees respectivement a 126 ¼ et 5 3/8.

Outre les plus values que nous venons de signaler, il faut noter encore la Behera qui gagne 7/8, les Markets 1 sh. 9 pence, la Crown Brewery 10 francs, la Cassa di Sconto 13 francs ½, la Delta Land 3/16 et les Estates 7/32.

L'Anglo-Egyptian Land Allolment dont nous avions prevu la hausse dans notre chronique de vendredi dernier, s'avance de 3 13/16 a 4 1/16 l'action et de P.T. 125 a 158 la part le fondateur. C'est lundi prochain, 12 conrant, que doit avoir lieu l'assemblee generale de la societe pour deliverer sur les decisions a prendre, en particulier sur les decisions a prendre, en particulier sur la creation d'une banque agricole a Chypre.

Le dividende de l'Egpytian Investment and Agency etait officiellement connu depuis longtemps; aussi n'est-ce pas sans etonnement qu'on a vu cette valeur flechir a la nouvelle de la confirmation du dividende annonce. Il n'en reste pas moins vrai que I'Investment possede a sa tete un conseil d'administration des plus serieux, ce qui est une bonne garantie pour les actionnaires. De plus, les pourparlers en vue de la formation d'une banque commerciale avec le concours d'une banque de Londres, un moment suspendus, viennent d'etre repris.
Apres avoir atteint 12 5/8, la Delta Light a reactionne a 12 pour remonter bientot apres a 12 1/8 acheteurs. Ce prix laisse une forte marge de hausse.

Le tribunal du Caire a prononce la faillite de la societe des Sucreries, qui a immediatement interjete appel de ce jugement. L'affaire veindra devant la Cour en audience speciale lundi prochain 12 courant. Il est a souhaiter dans l'interet des actionnaires et de l'agriculture egyptienne que le Course prononce contre la faillite, tout eu reservant, pour prevenir le retour de pareils abus, le recours contre les miserables (administrateurs) qui ont enisine des bilans factices et ruine une foule d'honneres gens.
L'Alexandria Central Building Co. vient de reussier a Londres le placement de £100,000 d'obligations 4% avec remboursement au gre de la societe, moyennant un simple prevais d'un mois.

A l'assemblee generale de la Compagnie des Eaux du Caire, tenue vendredi dernier il a ete decide de distribuer un dividende de 5 franc-aux actions de capital, 8, 25 aux actions de jonissance et 50, 60 aux parts de fondateurs.
La Banque d'Athenes, ayant accepte d'incorporer dans son conseil d'Administration deux membres francais, a ete admiseau Parquet de la Bourse de Paris.
Les Egyptian Estates veinnent de vendre, avec un benefice de 120% une partie du terrain schete a M. Alderson a Bulkeley (Ramleh).

On se rapelle que les bar quiers et les courtiers du Caire avaient nomme une commission mixte pour trancher le differend qui les divisait aur la question de l'emplacement de la bourse. Or, mercredi dernier, les courtiers ont fait choix de l'ex-terrain Sabet, sans prendre l'avis de cette commission.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIA
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalite met en adjudication les travaux de construction de la toiture de l'atelier des Ecuries Municipales de Chatby.
Le cautionnement est fixe a LE. 20 (Vingt).
Le cahier des charges est depose au Bureau Technique ou il peut etre consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adressees sous pli cachete a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 13 mars courant.
Elles pourront egalement etre deposees en stance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour construction de la toiture de l'atelier des Ecuries Municipales de Chatby."

Le cautionnement on le recu d'une banque, d'apres les conditions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis separement au Service de la Comptability Generale avant l'onverture des offres et au plus tard le 13 mars courant a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera ecartee.
L'Administrateur,
(Signe) W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 6 Mars 1906. 27443-3-2
AVIS

La Municipalite met en adjudication l'impression en Francis des proces-verbaux de la Commission, de la Delegation Municipales et autres imprimes necessaires a l'Administration pour une periode de deux ans, commerncant le 1er Avril 1906, jusqu'au 31 Mars 1908.
Le cantionnement est fixe a L E. 100.
Le cahier des charges est depose au Bureau de la Comptabilite Generale ou il peut etre consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adressees sons pli cachete a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 20 Mars prochain.
Elles pourront egalement etre deposees en seance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour Impression en Francais."

Le cautionnement ou le recu d'une banque, d'apres les conditions du cahier des charges devra etre remis separament au Service de la Comptabilite Generale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 20 Mars 1906 a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera ecartee.
L'Administrateur,
(Signe) W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 7 Mars 1906. 27457-3-1
AVIS

La Municipalite d'Alexandrie a l'honneur d'informer le public que par mesure tout a fait exceptionnelle et sans que cette derogation a la loi forme un precedent a l'avenir la Delegation Municipale a consenti a reporter au 31 mars courant le delai extreme dans lequel les proprietaires de bestiaux et vehicules sont admis d'apres le nouveau reglement a faire la declaration ecrite des voitures et betes dont ils sont posseesseurs.

Les personnes qui n'auraient pas jasqu'a present fait cette declaration, sont donc, invites a la faire avant le nouveau delia accorde par la Delegation, a defaut de quoi l'amende reglementaire leur sera appliquee.
Aucune excuse ne sera acceptee pour defaut de declaration apres le dit delai.
L'Administrateur,
(Signe) W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 7 Mars 1906. 27456-1-3

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
